question: A stretched wire of a material whose Young's modulus <katex>$Y=2\times10^{11}Nm^{-2}$</katex> has Poisson's ratio 0.25. Its lateral strain <katex>$\epsilon_{l}=10^{-3}$</katex> The elastic energy density of the wire is
explanation: Poisson's ratio <katex>$\sigma = \text{lateral strain} / \text{longitudinal strain}$</katex>. Long. strain <katex>$\epsilon = \epsilon_l / \sigma = 10^{-3} / 0.25 = 4 \times 10^{-3}$</katex>. Energy density <katex>$u = \frac{1}{2} Y \epsilon^2 = \frac{1}{2} (2 \times 10^{11}) (4 \times 10^{-3})^2 = 10^{11} (16 \times 10^{-6}) = 16 \times 10^5$</katex>.
